column1: Knee arthroscopy is surgery that uses a tiny camera to look inside your knee.
Three different types of pain relief (anesthesia) may be used for knee arthroscopy surgery: - Local anesthesia.
The pain medicine is injected around the nerve in your groin.

Meniscus is cartilage that cushions the space between the bones in the knee.

The risks for anesthesia and surgery are: - Allergic reactions to medicines - Breathing problems - Bleeding - Infection Additional risks for this surgery include: - Bleeding into the knee joint - Damage to the cartilage, meniscus, or ligaments in the knee - Blood clot in the leg - Injury to a blood vessel or nerve - Infection in the knee joint - Knee stiffness
